instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3432: What is 820-3432? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3432</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
It appear I need to replace <CAPACITOR>C8312</CAPACITOR> as I am getting no voltage from it and it looks a bit ugly. However in an attempt to replace it I have misplaced the little bugger on my trash board, how would I go about finding equivalent caps on the trash board I have? Or would I need to buy a new trash board from aliexpress.

Thanks.

[ATTACH type="full" width="60%"]10268._xfImport[/ATTACH]

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3432</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is the name of the brd file on the mid 2013 macbook air.  I don't know what it is either. So the <CAPACITOR>C8312</CAPACITOR> chip is not required and I should remove it instead of replacing it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3432</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
[B]<CHIP>U8300</CHIP> pins 2&3 are 3.3v; nothing on pins 4 & 5
<CAPACITOR>C8309</CAPACITOR> is 3.3v
<CAPACITOR>C8311</CAPACITOR> is 0
<CAPACITOR>C8312</CAPACITOR> is removed

I have replaced <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> and still getting the same results

Any ideas what to test next?

Thanks in advance[/B]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3432</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
So before I took it apart it had chime and green light.
Now no chime and no green light :(

I took the following measurements from <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>:

1) 0.58
2) 0.1
3) 128.33
4) 127
5)gnd
6) 17.77
7)NC
8) 17.77

Pin 4 was shorting to ground. Replaced <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, and tested it for shots to ground before powering it on. Now after powering it on the I am getting a short to ground on pin 4.

The numbers I am getting are obviously so far wrong I don't know what to do. This is my first board I have tried to fix so please don't abuse me too much duke... :)

[img]http://i.imgur.com/ORtCOku.jpg[/img]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3432</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
3v42 reads 0.1v. Testing in continuity mode suguests it is shorted to ground. Is this where I should be focusing my research?

EDIT: I am about to remove L7095 and test for a short either side as per Louis instructions here: [URL="https://youtu.be/ymMmi0790AY?t=838"]How does <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> circuit work and does it require <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to operate?[/URL]

EDIT2: short to ground still exists on bottom pad. Are there any tips to finding what is shorting it to ground or should i just start pulling up everything one by one until the short is gone?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3432</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message: Inject voltage and see what heats up, start low at 1V and see how much current it draws and go up from there. You fried this board.....

threads.message: I 100% fried the board. Is it salvageable? Where is the best place to learn how to not fry boards or is it just experience?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3432</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message: On the shorted rail, easiest at the coil. Start with low voltage and never go over the normal voltage that is normally on the rail. Observer the current, 2-3 amps should heat something up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3432</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
No, something is wrong here. If you have 18v on SHDN pin, 18v on VIN, and no short to ground on output... no. You're screwing something up that you're not telling us. Please tell us. 

Some more.

1) Is the voltage on VIN pin of <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> STABLE, or does it go up and down?

2) Are you measuring for a short to ground on L7095 with power plugged in? If so, DON'T! Measure without power plugged in. 

3) Where did this <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> chip come from?

4) Are you using too much heat and roasting it?

5) Are you sure this is soldered properly?

There is not much to this.
